snippet.textDisplay: It's not about change.  It's about RATE OF CHANGE.  We are in the 6th extinction and this one is man made.  And this idea that man was once in perfect harmony with nature needs to be done away with.  Hunter-gatherers did incredible damage everywhere they went.  Every continent they showed up on, megafauna disappeared at the same time.  What a coincidence.  Homo sapiens have been a blight on this planet for 300,000 years and resource management will be our downfall.  Anyone looking at the data should be terrified.  Absolutely terrified.

Yup ! Le climat a toujours changé bro !

Des bizous de la petite Sibérie Francaise.
ChuZ

snippet.textDisplay: I agree with the solution you propose, but climate is cyclical and there are absolutely companies that exist who engineer weather patterns.  In the USA, you can pay someone to cloud seed rain.  If private companies are doing that, then there’s also the potential for some major fuckery to be going on behind the scenes.  It’s not an impossibility.  It’s what we don’t know we don’t know.  Not what we know we know.

snippet.textDisplay:
Oh que tu as raison. Nos sociétés sont dans le déni totalement. Quand le pétrole et le gaz naturel se feront de plus en plus rares d'ici quelques décennies, nous ne pourrons plus fabriquer les engrais chimiques ni utiliser de la machinerie à grande échelle ni transporter les légumes sur des centaines de km. Le déclin de l'énergie abondante peu chère approche à grands pas. Nos ancêtres ramassaient des patates, les générations futures ramasseront des patates. Sans énergie abondante, c'est le déclin annoncé de l'agriculture à grande échelle. Sans parler de l'érosion des sols en moyenne de 50% au monde. Nous avons étiré le
processus trop longtemps. En plus que le climat va nous en faire voir de toutes les
couleurs. Ceux qui ne voient pas cela sont totalement dans le déni. Plusieurs sont des cornupuciens. Jean-Martin, bravo pour ta lucidité et merci d'éveiller les consciences. En passant, le pic de production de pétrole serait d'ici 1-2-3 ans...malgré que le pic de production de pétrole conventionnel a été en 2008 😬.

snippet.textDisplay:
There obviously is climate change. But I do think it is within normal climate fluctuation as well as we can measure them in the past. I also think more atmospheric C02 may be the link to producing more food and slowing desertification.
Man kind does contribute to climate change. But I think there are other more important and powerful factors.
I also remember when all packaging was paper, wood, glass, or metal. No plastic.Things that had a less permanent impact on our health and the worlds ecology. We were much healthier. I do think there is a connection to all the products and by products of our modern chemical world. In spite of the government and the industrial complex telling you that these are safe and there is nothing to worry about. Nearly all of these things eventually get dumped into a, creek, stream, river or ocean. Most of these things eventualy end up in the ocean. That is the real catastrophe we are creating and face.

snippet.textDisplay: Here in Northwestern Ontario, we should have 4-5 feet of snow in February. Right now, snow is barely covering the ground. Leeks, chives and rhubarb are emerging, two months ahead of schedule. Daytime and overnight temps are unusually high for this time of year. Open water on many ponds, lakes, creeks and rivers. The unseasonably warm weather is not cause for celebration. If this continues, we may have another brutal summer of forest fires and low water levels in our rural wells. Community farms + seed saving = food resiliency.

snippet.textDisplay: Here’s the thing - big ag is not sustainable and it is incapable of feeding the world. Supermarkets and the channel of distribution add huge costs to food. Why not support local farmers and enable them to enjoy a larger piece of the food chain pie?  What’s wrong with that especially when we all get food security and better control over what we grow and eat locally. People need to place a higher value on what they eat - no one complains about the excessive cost of sports tickets or concerts. Why the fuss about paying more for good local food. Or another option. Grow your own food

snippet.textDisplay: I'm coming at this from an interesting viewpoint.  I grew up on a medium sized commercial farm (~3000 acres) in central NY state. I'm also professionally trained as a climate scientist currently working at a university. I share your concerns about resilience of our food systems, but I would push back on the idea of 100% investment in small farms. Our success over the next century as a species is going to depend on the redundancies inherent to a combined approach: agriculture working at large scale, on small farms, and with hydroponics.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm coming at this from an interesting viewpoint.  I grew up on a medium sized commercial farm (~3000 acres) in central NY state. I'm also professionally trained as a climate scientist currently working at a university. I share your concerns about resilience of our food systems, but I would push back on the idea of 100% investment in small farms. Our success over the next century as a species is going to depend on the redundancies inherent to a combined approach: agriculture working at large scale, on small farms, and with hydroponics.

snippet.textDisplay:
JM, I'm worried also. I've been farming since 1976 and in the last 10 years I've become more and more concerned about the climate. Here in Michigan, like everywhere else, we are seeing extremes every month. Extremely wet or dry, humidity, wind storms,fire, flood. A few years ago 60% of our local farmers couldn't plant spring crops due to flooding and relied on government insurance to keep them solvent. Thankfully I use crop diversity rather than insurance to be successful.
The pace of change is going to force all of us to adapt. I'm worried..but also hopeful. Change can create opportunities. I think now is a good time for young vigorous people to become small farmers. They may be our salvation against starvation

A few years ago 60% of our local farmers couldn't plant spring crops due to flooding and relied on government insurance to keep them solvent. Thankfully I use crop diversity rather than insurance to be successful. 
The pace of change is going to force all of us to adapt. I'm worried..but also hopeful. Change can create opportunities. I think now is a good time for young vigorous people to become small farmers. They may be our salvation against starvation

snippet.textDisplay: I’m a small agroecologic farmer here in Puerto Rico. Huracanes are way more intense and frequent here in the Caribbean.  Now scientists here are talking about the possibility of adding a new Category which now is from 1 to 5 they will add Cat. 6 - never seen before. Ocean temperature in the Caribbean and Atlantic sea are now during winter months (Jan-Feb) as hot as they were during last summer June 2023 which btw was the hotter summer ever recorded. We here are getting ready for extreme weathers (excess rain - High tunnles and extreme droughts - with a well). You are right on your points. Good luck out there and keep up planning and adapting. Salud y bendiciones!! 🇵🇷

snippet.textDisplay:
Hydroponics, at feed the population sale, is a joke. Yet an investors pipe dream. It's sexy. Borders on being techy. And that attracts capital. Oh, but that capital will get burned, and burned, and burned. Substandard food, grown on nothing but chemical inputs, can never, ever, replace what real soil can produce. Thinking of the soil's integrated ecosystem of micro-biology, that does most the work, far above what chemicals could ever do. Another 1000 years of scientific advancements couldn't get to where life evolution has gotten, and is still in the process of going.

That said, the sheer numbers of small farms needed to replace industrial large scale AG, should climate change and de-globalization make those forms of farming no longer feasible, is astronomical. EU farmers can protest and hold up traffic as much as they want, on their largely subsidized crops, but the writing is on the wall.

Some forms of large scale AG will persist. I'm thinking most commodity grain crops like wheat, corn, soy, rice, canola, etc. And adjacent to that, as some of those crops are grown as feed, some large scale animal farming (beef, pork, chicken) will persist, to an extent. Commodity fruit like apples, banana's and oranges will persist as big mono-crops - orchards and vineyards - though many will have to move to other locations. And depending on how climate change progresses, maybe they move every decade or so. Chasing favorable temperature profiles and moisture regimes.

But, should global forces encourage more small, and medium, scale farming of the seasonal veg crops like lettuce, radish, beets, carrots, onions, etc., etc., etc., that whole market will change. In terms of where and how it is sold. Big time. It will no longer be about selling direct to consumer, at nice prices, to the bourgeoisie that currently are happy to pay premiums at the local Farmers Market. There will be lots of competition in the market, driving prices down, and now the small scale farmers, lots of them, are feeding the average joe population that just want/need decent, healthy enough, sustenance. Multitudes of small farmers supplying grocery stores is where it'll likely head.

Not next year, mind you. I'm thinking 10 -20 years out. In the mean time, I think we're already seeing the market just start to move in those directions.

snippet.textDisplay:
For the last 9 years here in B.C., we have been experiencing colder winters, later springs, and earlier falls. This year is very much an exception out here.
We are still coming out of a mini ice age that lasted until the late 1800's, so of course the ice is melting as we come out of that time. Before the mini ice age,( during the dark ages), there was a very warm period for several hundred years. It was largely because of this very warm period that the Vikings expanded as far as North America and became great traders into Russia and beyond. This is also a major reason for the rise of the Mongolian empire during that time. Warmer temperatures in the past were a time of flourishing prosperity. I care very much about taking care of the environment, but I don't buy into the ridiculous fear mongering. This earth always has the same amount of water. Some places get dryer and some places get wetter. The Sahara was once lush. We just have to be able to adapt.

Salut JM!
Je débute ma troisième saison comme maraîcher sur petite surface et je suis derrière toi à 100%. Les sols des grandes surfaces brûlent de plus en plus sans non plus y ramener la vie! Les insectes indésirables se multiplient tandis que les prédateurs diminuent. Les gens achètent du « tout prêt à manger » au lieu d’encourager la nourriture locale et produite de façon BIO! J’ai un petit kiosque dans un quartier d’environ 200 maisons (situé à un 4 coins) et c’est à peine si 2% arrêtent pour acheter leurs légumes. Facile comme solution hydroponique au lieu de trouver des solutions et aider notre planète! Que dire aussi des valeurs nutritives retrouvées dans les légumes du commerce… faut se poser la question ! Il n'y a presque pas eu de neige en Montérégie, j’ai vu le gazon presque tout l’hiver…ça prend d’la neige !!!! ENTK je suis avec toi et il faut plus de petites fermes et il faut soutenir notre communauté!
Je vais passer au Moulin bientôt
Merci JM et à la prochaine

snippet.textDisplay:
I think not enough people are talking about how these seasonal volatility will wipe out crops on a massive scale. when all my fruit trees pop blossoms early because of this warm weather and all die off because of a late (normally timed frost). how much crop loss will be had in the fruit production industries, and what is that going to do to prices.
additionally: just because it is warm out, does not mean you have enough sunlight to actually make this time productive. there are too many issues associated with the changing seasons. And I can see the frustration with you JM trying to put that into one video. I understand the risks at stake and get overwhelmed trying to communicate that to people in a quick summary.

snippet.textDisplay:
Climate change is here. There's a lot of room for more small farms that can sustain their owners.
It's probably not a one time fit all everywhere. Some dry regions should not grown nuts requiring tons of water but small farm would be better there. Some other regions were water is abundant want to have some hydroponic? Why not.
30-40% of the population don't have the financial resource to always have small farms produce at their existing prices, so (less) bigger farms are still required if that market segment wants to eat vegetables.
Small still have a lot of room for growth but it won't be a one size fit all everywhere.

The chemicals lobbies are currently too strong and use the same tactics as cigarettes industrie in the 60s. They seed the doubts and they discredit the agriculture based on natural cycles. Besides, many agronomes get commissions on the sales of chemicals so how do you want them to educate conventional farmers to switch to a more sustainable agriculture?
I agree that small farms are the solution but do we have enough man power to create all these small farms we need to feed everybody?

I am really afraid that we are going to face dramatic changes in a near future that will drastically increase massive migrations, social conflicts, wars between countries, civil wars which will lead to famines, diseases and then millions of deaths all around the world.
I am sad to realize that humans are unable to act to prevent an uncertain event, so we will inevitably physically suffer before altering our behavior.

snippet.textDisplay: Hi JM, have you read the book "A Small Farm Future" by Chris Smaje?  It sketches out the arguments you have made in this video.  I am with Farming Falmouth, a nonprofit in Massachusetts, and we are structuring an upcoming educational event "The Crucial Importance of Small Farms" which will seek to educate our locality intensively about this topic.

snippet.textDisplay:
Too few are willing to speak out, but this past 'winter' really should be a wake up call. Trace snow remaining here half-way between Ottawa and Montréal. Yes, the Canadians who love to complain about their snow are complaining about the lack of it!

Practically no one seems to want to take on the carbon emissions that are caused by oxidation of soil carbon when conventional agriculture's tills the soil. The world needs more nutrient dense food and less desertification. Gabe Brown is another who talks sense on this subject.

snippet.textDisplay: I think we also have to be careful about using F1 hybrids for everything we grow. Being able to save seeds is going to be so important in the future.  This also applies to animal farming, specifically chickens that are all hybrids these days.  We need to bring back the old heritage breeds that are hardier and can be locally adapted to each specific region where they are raised.  They can be bred by the farmer which eliminates the big corporate players who currently dominate our food (Cornish Cross genetics are owned by Tyson and a few other mega corporations).

snippet.textDisplay: It's refreshing to hear you talking about Climate Change.  Here in the US, usually mentioning climate change is a taboo thing because there are so many deniers here.  But, you're right, things are changing quickly.  Our winters have been so unpredictable the last few years.  We've had periods of extreme warmth as well as unusual blasts of cold too.  There are periods of extreme rain and periods of extreme drought.  It's actually making farming even harder.  Even the native plants are struggling at times. Starting to find ways to cope with these changes now is essential to feeding ourselves in the future.

snippet.textDisplay: Oh  dear maybe the bigger point is that current Big Ag farming practices are depleting soils world wide and the science does in fact predict that staying with the current mono farming soil depleting methods will mean the world has 60 harvests left.  Not good management - what does need managing is our soil and the microbiome necessary for the production of nutrient dense food.  Climate change is a thing because man has accelerated processes that are ultimately harmful to all life and we are slow walking into the next human extinction if there are no interventions.  The planet will survive but life on this planet will look much different if we don't intervene with more sustainable practices - Farming - deciding what to produce,where to produce and how to produce will be a big part of the solution and community-based  regenerative farming is a great place to start.

There are some great quotables here to be pulled for social media!

I find it hard not to think of hydroponic systems as an option for urban gardening. We moved from Montreal to the Lanaudière in 2021, and quickly I realised hydroponics are not right for my home, where I have a shallow well, high water table and 50k sq.ft to consider working with sustainably.

snippet.textDisplay: Only in the top inch or so. The flame is much more dangerous to the tender weeds. The soil life biota repopulates easily enough. The soil life your annual veg relies upon is deeper down in the soil nearer the root zone of your seedlings. Likely less damage overall than pulling tender weeds & disturbing the soil.

snippet.textDisplay: We build our permanent raised beds 50 feet long thinking it was an even number without realizing that the tarps/cloths often need excess at the ends for securing. Now our beds are 45 feet long so the 50 foot material is more effective. ❤

snippet.textDisplay: When you don't have your tarps deployed out on your beds how do you store them? Just folded up in the field?
snippet.textOriginal: When you don't have your tarps deployed out on your beds how do you store them? Just folded up in the field?

snippet.textDisplay: We store our tarps beside the feild blocks they cover as they are pretty heavy to move far distances. Plus that has the added benefit of keeping perennial weeds from encroaching on the outer garden beds! ❤

snippet.textDisplay: The various tools you see in action only work the top 1-2" of soil to make a quality seed bed for planting. No layers of soil are flipped and the structure of the bed remains intact. The only time the soil is more disturbed is when creating beds initially, and when raising them occasionally over time. Beds can settle over time so we will toss soil from the row back on to the top of the bed, but this still doesn't effect the deeper layers. The goal is always minimal disturbance!
snippet.textOriginal: The various tools you see in action only work the top 1-2" of soil to make a quality seed bed for planting. No layers of soil are flipped and the structure of the bed remains intact. The only time the soil is more disturbed is when creating beds initially, and when raising them occasionally over time. Beds can settle over time so we will toss soil from the row back on to the top of the bed, but this still doesn't effect the deeper layers. The goal is always minimal disturbance!

snippet.textDisplay: I have used this technique on my own farm in the past and decided it is not working for our climate and location. Our windy dry winters caused the soil to be eroded away and the beds flattened out by the time spring came around. I find in our region a permanent wood Mulch on perfectly flat blocks of beds with yearly compost additions gently scratched into the Mulch is an incredibly productive system. This also allows me to adjust the width of the planting beds and blocks at will depending on the requirements for production. An area that was a pathway between two narrow beds can be planted over into a wider bed with no loss in production because the soil never becomes compacted under the wood Mulch. A thin layer of wood chips spread every fall or spring is plenty to keep the soil covered year-round. And can be planted directly into with seeders.

snippet.textDisplay: If you had a small tractor would you use it? Just curious on the tractor hate. Seems like it could do the same thing as the BCS and also make spreading compost/ making compost way easier for your employees.
snippet.textOriginal: If you had a small tractor would you use it? Just curious on the tractor hate. Seems like it could do the same thing as the BCS and also make spreading compost/ making compost way easier for your employees.

snippet.textDisplay:
We don't hate tractors at all! We're simply teaching a system of farming that is optimized for the use of a BCS and hand tools and therefore doesn't require a tractor. That being said a tractor can be a great help on a farm for moving large loads of compost around and doing larger land works, and we have used small tractors for these things over the years as well. Plenty of market gardeners use tractors, but just as many do it without even a BCS! The message is that you don't NEED a tractor in order to have a successful small farm, and that allows many more people to get started in this amazing world of market gardening! 💚
- Chris MGI

snippet.textDisplay: The tools we use on the BCS for bed preparation only mix the top 1"-2" of soil, to make a high quality seed bed for planting. This is still considered "no-till" because we are not inverting layers of soil. It's the equivalent of thoroughly raking the surface of your seed bed to break up any clumps of soil. We understand that this can be confusing though, and we also often promote the term "minimal tillage" as plenty of successful organic growers till their soil to some degree. Regardless of labels, the goal of building heathy soil revolves around minimal disturbance and supporting the life in the soil, through whichever means the farmer chooses. Hope this helps! 🙂
snippet.textOriginal: The tools we use on the BCS for bed preparation only mix the top 1"-2" of soil, to make a high quality seed bed for planting. This is still considered "no-till" because we are not inverting layers of soil. It's the equivalent of thoroughly raking the surface of your seed bed to break up any clumps of soil. We understand that this can be confusing though, and we also often promote the term "minimal tillage" as plenty of successful organic growers till their soil to some degree. Regardless of labels, the goal of building heathy soil revolves around minimal disturbance and supporting the life in the soil, through whichever means the farmer chooses. Hope this helps! 🙂

snippet.textDisplay:
In my 30 inch/75 cm beds I do 4 rows for lettuce, carrots, onions, and beets. 5 rows for radish, green onion, and cilantro. I could do 6 rows on those crops, the soil fertility could handle it, but then weeding becomes too problematic at that tight a spacing. 7 to 9 rows for arugula - it grows so fast weeding is not an issue there. Bigger crops like kale get staggered planted in two rows. Medium sized like fennel might go 3 rows. Even bigger like eggplant or tomatoes are just one row down the middle of the bed. Bush beans are two rows.

Pack them in as tight as your soil fertility can handle, and your cultivation tools/methods can manage. At maturity the plants should be touching each other. Like Happy Hills Farms said in their reply, create a full canopy so your crop shades the soil to minimize weed growth underneath, and to maximize yield.

Going to 90cm instead of 75cm will make the beds just that much wider that straddling the beds, with one foot on each side, to do bent over hand work, will be just that much harder to handle with your legs spread farther apart. That's one of the key points of the 75 cm/30 inch bed system.

Or, as some do, forgo straddling the beds and only work from the sides reaching in. There you may consider going with 120 cm/48 inch beds. Cuts down on total area of walking paths and puts more ground into production. You're only reaching 60cm/2 feet from one side or the other. In that system, using the spacing I mentioned above, you could run 7 or 8 rows of lettuce in one bed. Or 4 rows of lettuce down one side and 4 or 5 rows of green onion down the other side. Lots of options.

snippet.textDisplay: @@stevehatcher7700Thx for the reply. Well im not goin to straddle over much since it feels very bad to me. 120cm beds are best in tractor cultivated systems so i dont consider them an option.  I guess we are talking about different salads. If i do headlettuce 7-8 rows on a 75cm bed, i would never get any good product. In the european market we usually aim for at least 300gr. lettuce heads often the market even requires 400gr.+ No matter how good my soil fertility is, its not possible closer then 25 cm usually 30 cm. Some farms even go 37,5cm between roaws and 25-20 in row spacing. The beds are completely covered up by the salad heads within a few weeks. My experience on a small trial field i did was that if you go 3 rows x 30 cm on a 75cm bed it doesnt work since the bed crumbles away to easy at the edges, especially under dry conditions.

snippet.textOriginal: yes, and it is a big expense.   Can't get around that

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't have access to enough compost, in my location, at any price, that would satisfy my quality standards. So I only make my own. It's only enough to apply a little to each bed at each planting succession. Really just enough to inoculate the bed with good microbes, and a little bit more organic matter than what was there. Not inches deep as a mulch layer to suppress weeds and planting into the compost, as is often preached by many market gardeners here on the You Tubes. You might want to purchase enough to do that in year one to really boost your soil organic matter. Running that much compost, year after year, can create issues down the road with phosphorous build up. Particularly if the compost contains animal manures. Phosphorous is not a very mobile nutrient. It flows through soil at less than an inch per year.

But, like me, not using that much compost means you do need to use a fair bit of other fertility inputs. I use a mix of pelletized chicken manure, alfalfa meal, bone meal, blood meal and kelp meal. Still a considerable expense each year. But if I didn't pony up that expense.... I'd end up farther and farther behind each year. It's an investment towards increased profitability, not just a dead end expense.

Oh, and I don't raise my beds. Flat land. Silt Loam soil. The effort to raise the beds seems lost on me, for my soil. Run-off down into walkways. Every few years digging up, or rotary plowing walkways back up into the beds. Ugg. Work. And my very silty loam can dry out fast and turn almost clay like, at times. In a raised environment that may happen more often. Much higher levels of compost (organic matter) may mitigate that, but I, currently, just can't get enough to achieve it. The beds do end up raised about an inch though, between the no-till(ish) decompaction in the beds themselves and the compaction in the walkways.

snippet.textDisplay: Tough to enter the software market space.  Seedtime and tend are decently mature products.  Problem right now is everyone is using their own differentiators when customers would probably prefer all of their problems be solved.  Pre-populated tasks for crops, mapping, crop planning, secession planning, revenue management, cash flow management, online sales channel integrations, seed ordering, custom pricing, inventory management, labor management, time & expense management.  Right now it is just a hodgepodge of everyone picking out something different and trying to establish market domination.  And since the market isn't that large to begin with, you're just chipping away at each others profitability.

snippet.textDisplay: It is a bit rough but I like where I think this is heading. I worked in software product management for many years and I have a ton of feedback. Please let me know how I can get that to the dev team. My first bit of feedback would be that it could use a few short video tutorials. There were a number of places where someone who was familiar with the intended workflow would have had not trouble but where I got stuck. Also as a smaller scale market gardener there were a few places where I got tripped up. For example despite have uniform beds I probably should have chosen row feet as my units instead of beds. I have a lot of crops that I just can't justify a whole bed to. A lot of my succession planting is seeding a full row down a bed with the Jang and then using the next row in that bed a week later. I also do a lot of things like 3 cultivars seeded at once in a single bed to keep people excited while not over producing the total quantity of that vegetable.

C'est le vrai challenge aujourd'hui..

snippet.textDisplay: I like this conversation.  I started small while working full time at a farm.  Each year as my home based farm stand has grown I've pulled time working for other farmers and put it towards my farm.  I have also started doing pop ups around my town.  The most important thing I've found is to start even if it's not perfect.  Then each week I try to make it better.  Working on farms for a few years before I started was also essential.  Thanks again keep up the good work.

snippet.textDisplay:
Oh boy does this interview resonate with me about ‘failing’ in my own backyard is what’s challenged me to learn what I’m doing wrong and make it ‘right’.

I decided to turn my oasis yard into a temporary ‘test garden’ so I can fail fast in preparation for wanting to have a farm for a living in the future.

With all our companies we started as a side hustle and did a slow grow which in my opinion is the way to go because it’s waaaaaay less stressful and risky.

So I sincerely thank you for this reminder as my impatience is creating stress to make this leap.

Taking a step back to design the context, plan priority buildouts, getting clientele prepped annnnnd I think I can resume breathing ? 🤔😅

Pete Larsen from the "Just a Few Acres Farm" YouTube channel has some great advice and videos of starting a farm.
Start small.
Also, for the small farmer, three components must be in
balance:
Infrastructure/product/market.
If one gets too ahead of the other the farm is at risk for failure.

snippet.textDisplay:
Increase sales, decrease costs, improve efficiency. Increase the total number of customers, increase the average order value, increase the frequency of purchase - Double down on the customers you already have. The cost of acquisition is less - consider the lifetime value of the customer and deliver more value for them. Ruthlessly eliminate unnecessary costs and waste . Leverage the costs that have the most return on investment. Spend more time on the crops that make the most money. Spend more time on tasks that return real value. Spend less time on things that don't return value.

We spent too much time at three markets last year that weren't the best. The opportunity cost of going to market was too high. It meant less time on the farm and more time and energy loading and unloading, driving, setting up and tearing down. These are valuable hours that could have went into production, cultivation, harvest, washing and packing or selling.

This year we're building a membership model and bringing the customers to us, so we can stay at the farm, produce more and spend less time, money and energy on markets. The main take away for us is producing and earning more with what we already have, just changing the way we do things. Create more value for the customer, find more time and energy in the production process, and more money in tweaking production, leveraging resources more efficiently and reducing unnecessary costs. Less is more.

Get more out the limited resources you have. Like JM said you need data and references in order to evaluate these things.

snippet.textDisplay:
​​@@ryancullen6706Going on 53 and about to enter year 5 -- get into the right tools that make the physical efforts easier, sooner rather than later!!! Your joints, ligaments and muscles will thank you for an extra decade!!!

Pro tip- tillage tools, with some thought, understanding, and experimentation, can be used in a no-till/low-till context. Depth control and speed control to work the soil to the same level as hand tools would achieve. Save hours and hours and wear and tear on the body!

snippet.textDisplay:
I am convinced that the snow contains many cool microbes, like PSB's etc that boost energy in to the system, especially as it melts. The cold water would also contain higher levels of DO2 so charging the aerobic microbes this boosting mineral availability so we see healthy growth thereafter. Also the cold slows the decomposition of organic material and humates form and again this boost mineral availability.
We have been trying a chitinase based product, made from fermentation of crab shell powder. This we have applied as a foliar around 2 weeks before the first frost. The chitin stimulates the plant to be more frost resistant,.like anti freeze. We think this is a SAR reaction but it helps for sure.
May be something you can try. Sure you have access to crab shells etc.

snippet.textDisplay: I grow all winter and provide produce to a local farm store in zone 8a which used to be zone 7b in a 50ft x 16ft gothic pro tunnel from Farmer's Friend converted to roll-up sides. I also use mini-hoops & row cover inside to cover the crops when the temperatures dip into the 20's. Key is like Catherine said is to establish the crops before the light levels drop  & cold temps arrive. We have a bit more time in North Carolina and don't have the extremes that Northern climates have. I am growing Tatsoi, Tokyo Bekana, Red Sails Lettuce, Cilantro, Salad mix, Arugula, and Collards. I have been doing this for several years successfully with no heat. The other key is to roll down the sides 2-3hrs before sunset to trap the heat in the tunnel & keep the ground warm.

snippet.textDisplay: I've been saying for years that farmers markets should be open year round. If you don't have a market to sell your produce, then your efforts are fruitless. Veggies don't know what day it is, or what time of year it is. They only know the growing conditions and that is where green houses come into the play.

snippet.textDisplay: @@79PoisonBreaker I don't think that is the case anymore for most of Canada, excluding the territories or anything below growing zone 2. There are some people in Canada that are innovating with greenhouses to make it more economical and viable for growers in colder climates. There are Chinese greenhouses (Insulated North side and insulated blankets at night) in northern alberta and there are greenhouses in the snow (Geothermal) greenhouses in Armstrong BC and another one in Alberta somewhere. It is coming to a point where there is enough technology that make greenhouses a bit more inexpensive and viable for people in Canada to use during the winter. It is very exciting IMO.
snippet.textOriginal: @@79PoisonBreaker I don't think that is the case anymore for most of Canada, excluding the territories or anything below growing zone 2. It is coming to a point where there is enough technology that make greenhouses a bit more inexpensive and viable for people in Canada to use during the winter. It is very exciting IMO.

snippet.textDisplay: Good question! This bed orientation is actually more because the greenhouse is toured every week by guests of the restaurant! It also creates many mini-beds which allow us to grow more varieties in a way that's easier to manage. But generally, most market gardeners will grow lengthwise to have enough supply of each crop for their various markets (and it keeps bed length standard between outside and inside which allows for easier crop planning)

snippet.textDisplay: The thinner the leaf, the more they tend to bolt in the heat…think lettuce, arugula, cilantro. They dont mind the cold but will not do as well as the thicker leaves like kale and spinach. Kale seems to tolerate heat and cold. Spinach hates the heat and is not a good summer crop unless you have shade cover or have lower temps in general
snippet.textOriginal: The thinner the leaf, the more they tend to bolt in the heat…think lettuce, arugula, cilantro. Spinach hates the heat and is not a good summer crop unless you have shade cover or have lower temps in general

snippet.textDisplay:
Lots of good stuff here..
The purpling I understand relates to phosphorus. As energy levels drop, the microbes that mobilise P are sleepy. So the plant, sensing the lowering of availability, scavenges all that it can..it's so unstable so the plant converts it to Anthocyanin, ergo the red and increased anti oxidant for us.
The Chinese cabbage. Have you tried a chamomile tea to see if you motivate better Sulfur mobilisation. Again another thing to suffer in the cold and low light.
Also N might slow and so perhaps a higher N rate in the base material?
Dandelion is a great plant. We have both the red one, camarojas or the green one dente del lion. Also winter purslane is super and lambs lettuce too.
The plant with mildew, perhaps you might try to add some horsetail to your compost base. Just a thought reference silica and PM. As it's a test area, may be you might see how this works out before abandoning the plants you find less impressive.
We have been using a liquid chitin product as a foliar about two weeks before the first frost. Haven't had to do it yet this year but it seems to help many plants resist the cold better.

Anyway thanks always

snippet.textDisplay: Good info. Here on the coast of NL our climate is maritime and winter temps rarely dip down below -10. Winter growing is fine except for the low light in late fall / early spring when we get ALOT of cloudy days...winters are usually really clear with lots of bluebird days. Issue I've run into with the greenhouses is if I don't freeze them out the bug pressure gets out of control. I've been putting the chickens in as part of a rotational plan to keep things balanced with insects and nitrogen. Salad mix is soo 2010 :) #coastalorganic
snippet.textOriginal: Good info. Here on the coast of NL our climate is maritime and winter temps rarely dip down below -10. Winter growing is fine except for the low light in late fall / early spring when we get ALOT of cloudy days...winters are usually really clear with lots of bluebird days. snippet.textDisplay:
Another great video, I like showcasing winter growing methods and greens and other crops that can take the cold. As mentioned in the video food sovereignty is critical, however keep in mind Johnny’s has around 40 varieties of lettuces that have patents on them, either the traits or the whole variety. In my view you can’t have food sovereignty without seed sovereignty, in those cases where you grow a patented variety you can be litigated for saving seed, in other words you are at the mercy of the company that holds the patent.
For this reason I won’t buy from Johnny’s or others that sell patented seeds, if you choose to buy from them avoid the patented varieties, this sends a message that you care about open source seeds. Some growers may not. Care, but I sure do.
If a company decides to drop a variety you are also out of luck especially if it had a patent on it.
That aside this video is important, just keep in mind all the variables with seed too.
Really like the walk through videos and the interview format is good for a balance.

snippet.textDisplay: @@TheMarketGardeners thanks! I use #9 galvanized rolls of wire from tractor supply to make my field row covers. It’s about $27 for 170 feet. Cut them about 6’ lengths, the curve in the loose roll is perfect for beds. The attach cover to wire with mini binder clips. One on top and one on each side. Slide clip up on either side for bed access. Here is a video on it from our channel. https://youtu.be/45n1XlUJITQ?si=_D6Z2Rh2irLoaf00
snippet.textOriginal: @@TheMarketGardeners thanks!  I use #9 galvanized rolls of wire from tractor supply to make my field row covers.  It’s about $27 for 170 feet. snippet.textDisplay:
On young people being comfortable, obviously JM has experience trying to employ and train young people but these conversations always gloss over the fact that millenials were promised an easy life if they did as told and then as soon as they hit working age - poof. Millenials became the evil that plagued every industry for having expectations, for trying to get the comfort they were promised.

By demanding comfort for themselves they make business owners, managers, parents, conglomerates, etc uncomfortable by upsetting the status quo decided for them. There are piles of evidence showing how younger generations have had higher hurdles than their seniors yet its the youth who are wrong and weak for being asked to throw themselves unquestionably into the grinder to benefit others. Gen Z and Alpha see how millenials have been treated and are coming in swinging. I applaud them for making big business uncomfortable about how to appease their workers.

There's no 2 ways about it that farming is hard and people dont have an accurate idea of what you have to put in either as a worker or owner. Its incredibly frustrating as a manager but can you blame them? Every day big business and governments say we are not enough while lining their pockets with the fruit of our "insufficient" labor. How do we blame the young for fighting for respect and comfort in their lives at an affordable cost? In most cases the respect being asked for is for employers and coworkers to be civil, respect their boundaries, and treat them as an employee - not a punching bag or lifeline to save your business on minimum wage.

That being said, yes of course you need to put in work to get greater respect in life and the workplace. I can't help but wonder if JM gets more "green", starry eyed applicants due to his fame in the industry because I've yet to meet anyone in my area that thinks farming is or will be easy work.

snippet.textDisplay:
That’s what JM says about halfway through. People got the wrong idea about what the farm was supposed to be when they tried to make it a lifestyle for the people they were sharing their farm with, and those people became resentful when those unrealistic expectations weren’t met. So he changed the rules and said, “Look. I am the boss, you work for me, I pay you for helping me.” And everything was simplified through that.

Solo farms are cool depending on your personality, but I really see an exponential productivity by setting up jobs for people that I pay $16-$20/hour to do. With proper planning, you can get $50-$100/hour return on investment for that pay, so it’s well worth it in my view.

Apprenticeships, especially unpaid/underpaid ones, are a broken model in my view, so I don’t blame anyone for not getting involved with it.

Sure, teach the people who work for you so they can take on more management responsibilities on your farm, but why set up a relationship where someone is asking for free education in exchange for free labour?

They’ll get the education way better by working on a profitable farm that can actually afford to pay people for doing the work.

snippet.textDisplay: Oversimplifying things here, but there are really 2 economic classes in the West: businesses and regular consumers. Having some business accumen opens up expensing, commercial lending, superior agriculture lending from the USDA/FSA, superior lensing terms, insulation from liability.... The list goes on and on. Since the farm is generally also part of your residence, there is a lot of cross over to building out and improve your business location/home. Owning and operating a business, even one that is subsidized by your off-farm job, has a multitude of benefits. Spend the money to properly organize your business and start a tax paper trail. Talk to a CPA. Showing consistent sales and year over year growth can be a lot more helpful than unreported cash sales.

snippet.textDisplay: There's only so many wealthy people ready and able to buy your expensive organic hand-crafted food.  As a market gardener for the last 40 years, I've seen the growers get more and more removed from the bulk of society, today it's become a little subculture of growers and upper middle class customers.  I spent years trying to get people to come to our farmers' market, 95 percent of the time the response I got was "it's too expensive for me".  Until you can sell at a price people can afford, it's only going to be a small niche market.

snippet.textDisplay:
Small scale farming is a labor of love, and almost impossible these days to do in an economically viable way. As a family, the scale is too small to really support yourself. To bring on additional labor, then that generates a cost that is hard to swallow. Wages have to be high because it costs so much just to survive. I think that if free range eggs could be sold for $25 a dozen and an organic chicken at $50, then there would be room to make viable small scale farming. Most small scale farms seem to usually have some other source of income to keep things going. Either the wife works as a school teacher and pays the bills and gets health insurance, or the couple have some retirement or other type income.

When I was a boy growing up in the 1960's in West Texas, there were probably 700 small family based farms in the county. Today in that county there are maybe two or three farmers. They have purchased, or lease almost all the property. They have multi-million dollar tractors, and have basically a chemical/poison system of pouring chemicals on dead soil and poison the heck out of anything that wiggles.

It is very sad. The system seems to be hopelessly broken. I live in a slum in East Africa, and try and teach the indigenous people sustainable and regenerative agriculture. Here wages are low and families are large, so sustainable/regenerative agriculture actually can work better here than in the West.

Thanks for the video, it was well done.

His laborers are likely paid a set rate based on what their job performance is worth, regardless of what his yields are. Increasing his production output by 5x allows the business to make a larger profit, which in turn can be re-invested into the business.

snippet.textDisplay:
Grandparenting and farming go hand in hand (literally) as well. Yesterday we had two of our grandsons (8 years and 15 months) over for the day, and we took up the gladiolus for storage and the last of the potatoes. The toddler amazingly picked raspberries with such skill; carefully picking them one by one without smashing any and only taking the ripe ones.
My point is that there’s no better place for children to grow up than a farm; be it their parent’s or grandparent’s farm.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm trying to replicate your work to some extent in Japan, where absolutely nobody believes it can be done on a small scale. I'm going into my third year full-time and I really appreciated the commentary on this tour. I got frustrated last winter seeing your new big farm and Neversink and all these hugely successful run like a machine farms that I want to be like, and it just felt like I was failing. You reminded us here that this is not to brag, it's to show what's possible. Sometimes it's easy to forget that you and Connor have decades building these beautiful systems and are just showing us what is possible to grow the revolution.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm trying to replicate your work to some extent in Japan, where absolutely nobody believes it can be done on a small scale. snippet.textDisplay:
Bonjour de France Mr Martin =)
J'admire vos partage vidéo pour vôtre travail en maraichage sur petite surface. Je suis jardinier amateur, & cela fait 3 Ans que je pratique vos méthode sans travail du sol. J'habite en Normandie & j'ai une Terre très Argileuse donc dur dur de travailler avec. Je plante petit a petit des Haie comestible en tout genre & des arbres fruitier tout en gardant un sol vivant avec des engrais vert & pailler toute l'année. J'ai acheter tout vos livres & je me cultive également sur Verre de Terre production, & j'ai même visionner vos émission de la Ferme de la Grelinette. Et tente cette année un jardin d'hivers qui me semble compliqué a mettre en place. Ma fois continuer a nous partager vôtre passion depuis le Québec ;) A bientôt & bon courage. Bye Bye
snippet.textOriginal:
Bonjour de France Mr Martin =)
J'admire vos partage vidéo pour vôtre travail en maraichage sur petite surface. Je suis jardinier amateur, & cela fait 3 Ans que je pratique vos méthode sans travail du sol. Je plante petit a petit des Haie comestible en tout genre & des arbres fruitier tout en gardant un sol vivant avec des engrais vert & pailler toute l'année. J'ai acheter tout vos livres & je me cultive également sur Verre de Terre production, & j'ai même visionner vos émission de la Ferme de la Grelinette. Et tente cette année un jardin d'hivers qui me semble compliqué a mettre en place. Ma fois continuer a nous partager vôtre passion depuis le Québec ;) A bientôt & bon courage. Bye Bye

snippet.textDisplay: For the foreseeable future, inflation will put a bit of a damper on the development of this localized market. Paying a premium for local  and higher quality will be more of a pinch for that bulk of the market that sits in the middle of having that extra disposable income. However, in the near future, this becomes absolutly necessary in a world of reduced supply chains, and labour shortages, with massively shifting demographics as the boomer generation retires and, then, exits the population. Not to mention climate change. Very early days, still, but it's coming.

snippet.textDisplay: The biggest difference for me is you don’t have to wash flowers! I love growing veggies, but we’re switching to do more flowers. They make us so much more money in less bed space. However like she said if you don’t harvest at the right time the flowers become useless and go to seed so fast for some varieties. Neither my wife or live making bouquets, so we’re going to hire someone to take that on next year

snippet.textDisplay: One thing I will say though- although the washing of some veggies can be very time consuming, some flowers can be very time consuming to harvest. They you have to strip all the leaves off, & some have thin stems so you have to take off one at a time.  Then you have to put them one at a time in the bucket because the stems get tangled if you try to harvest & keep flowers in your hand & harvest more.  Just something to think about.

snippet.textDisplay:
The wood has to actually burn and then it’s turned out to make biochar. With coal, it’s deprived of oxygen and the product is much heavier and can slow burn to cook your food.
Unlike coal, you can’t actually relight biochar or use it to cook your food because it’s already been burnt. Two very different products.
Basically, biochar is the leftover embers once you turn out your fire, it’s light and crumbles into small pieces, coals stay hard and retain their weight and it’s what’s used for bbq…
snippet.textOriginal:
The wood has to actually burn and then it’s turned out to make biochar. With coal, it’s deprived of oxygen and the product is much heavier and can slow burn to cook your food. 
Unlike coal, you can’t actually relight biochar or use it to cook your food because it’s already been burnt. Two very different products.
Basically, biochar is the leftover embers once you turn out your fire, it’s light and crumbles into small pieces, coals stay hard and retain their weight and it’s what’s used for bbq…

snippet.textDisplay: Thanks JM,  you're my inspiration and validation. Compost is always fun to watch as the pile builds heat. But who has time to wait for it. After 29 years on my farm with time being always short, I've learned to skip the  whole process. When I'm ready to make a bed, I jump on my  30 hp tractor with a collection flail mower and go mow my acres of path ways and yards. I never use herbicides on my yards so they are thick with clovers. I make a windrow of 4'' clips 24 wide by 18'' high down the row and till it in with another 30 hp tractor with a 60'' tiller with a bed shaper on the back. I end up with a bed that has about 50% soil and 50% nitrogen rich clips that is mixed in 18'' deep. Where ever roots go there are decomposing clips. Between the beds I lay down 4'' of chopped hay with the same  collection mower. I raise watermelon and pumpkins and cover all the soil between rows with chopped hay from 75 acres of rolling hills two steep to cultivate. My thoughts on tractors are you should have one for each piece of equipment so I have six, all bought used over several years. Four are Massey 1250 's with 16 speed transmissions and four wheel drive. Lets say you have an hour before dark and you would like to mow but you have the tiller on so you can plant  another patch of corn in the morning. You don't have time to swap equipment twice  so the mowing  doesn't get done. The 1,000 tomatoes in the hoop houses get the same clips tilled in and seem  to do better each year. Why is time so important? I do 99% of all this by myself so every minute must be very productive and easier on my 68 year old body.  Your video on mental health and burn out was spot on, I pushed too hard for too many years fighting the weather and pests, loosing crops and coming up short at the end of the year. I backed off for a couple years until I found my center and fell back in love with growing food for others. Here in southeastern Ind. folks like their maters and corn and melons and not so much of the greens and root crops you all sell to folks in the city. We sell some but tomatoes are what I'm known for. As I type this,  I'm watching three customers  on camera up at the store, all using the honor system box. Several times this summer I've been away out picking  for  30 minutes and find over $100.00 in the unlocked box. After 29 years I've built a community of customers that support me and I rarely come up short and I  haven't had to put a photo on my wall of shame in three years. Keep posting videos, I love seeing your methods and crops, hey I even dig your accent.

My thoughts on tractors are you should have one for each piece of equipment so I have six, all bought used over several years. Four are Massey 1250 's with 16 speed transmissions and four wheel drive. Lets say you have an hour before dark and you would like to mow but you have the tiller on so you can plant  another patch of corn in the morning. You don't have time to swap equipment twice  so the mowing  doesn't get done. The 1,000 tomatoes in the hoop houses get the same clips tilled in and seem  to do better each year. Why is time so important? I do 99% of all this by myself so every minute must be very productive and easier on my 68 year old body.  Your video on mental health and burn out was spot on, I pushed too hard for too many years fighting the weather and pests, loosing crops and coming up short at the end of the year. I backed off for a couple years until I found my center and fell back in love with growing food for others. Here in southeastern Ind. folks like their maters and corn and melons and not so much of the greens and root crops you all sell to folks in the city. We sell some but tomatoes are what I'm known for. As I type this,  I'm watching three customers  on camera up at the store, all using the honor system box. Several times this summer I've been away out picking  for  30 minutes and find over $100.00 in the unlocked box. After 29 years I've built a community of customers that support me and I rarely come up short and I  haven't had to put a photo on my wall of shame in three years. Keep posting videos, I love seeing your methods and crops, hey I even dig your accent.

snippet.textDisplay:
Since I don't have a tractor with a front loader anymore, I make compost at low temperatures without turning. It takes 1 -2 years to get ready to use.
I used to add paperpot left overs as well, but the paper didn't decompose at all, just as with your pile. Now I rake the paperpot left overs out of my beds with a spring rake and put them in the burnable garbage bags.
For me the paperpot transplanter made a big difference. I use it mainly for beets and for spring planted "navet" (golden turnips). A big reason is that the germination is much better as I seed them in the greenhouse. Furthermore I spend much less time thinning the beets as I do it while they are still in the greenhouse. The first year using the paperpots for beets my sales went up 30%. It paid for the paperpot transplanter in the first year.

snippet.textDisplay: I like to think of charcoal / biochar as a better carbon 'battery' for the garden than traditional methods (compost). Lithium batteries revolutionized the battery market the same way biochar revolutionizes garden soil, especially for those who are building soil / working with heavy clay soils.  They last longer, hold more 'charge', etc.  Biochar is just inoculated clean charcoal - can be made from literally any carbon source through a variety of methods.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is not a plug for Paperpot, Paperpot is way too expensive for me.
Acetone is highly volatile, meaning it evaporates very readily. If you are making a hot compost, temperatures above 120 degrees Fahrenheit, there probably won't be any acetone in the final product.
Also, a hot compost will break the paper down. If you have paper in your compost, then it's not getting hot enough.
At least this is what I think I know.

snippet.textDisplay:
@@jeanmartinfortierprivateThe paper might mean your compost is a little dry? Also, you might want to try bringing in some red wiggler worms to add to your finished pile. They'll help clean all that up. Just add them to one pile, and they'll move around as they need to.

I had worm composts for years, and eventually I just dumped it all into a bin with finished compost, and now I find red wigglers anywhere organic material is. They move around on their own.

snippet.textDisplay:
I 've been filling 50 gallon plastic drums with food waste, adding bokashi inoculant. I use it to preserve/ferment the food scraps till I have enough to build a big compost. A big compost heats up fast, and keeps the rodents away.

A restaurant doesn't have that issue - they probably produce enough food scraps to make a big compost in a week.

snippet.textDisplay: So much stuff in this interview. You are right on how bad industrial wheat full of gluten is. It changed my life stopping eating it 15 years ago, but boy, natural wine, not for me. Bio wine yes, but natural wine is gimmick. That being said, the biggest problem with bio small farming is that poorer people cannot afford it, and I am not talking only about very poor people. Also, beyond farming, people need first to stop eating processed food before switching to bio veggies. If people would cook their own food, even with non bio vegetables and fruits, it would be an enormous good first step to stop the crazy way people are eating now in North America, with the obesity rate skyrocketing. Also I worked on a strawberries farm when I was young, it's very different from having your own relaétively small garden for your own needs or as a hobby like I do. It is a tough job physically, especially on the long run with the prospect of aging. Also, I watched the "Les Fermiers" TV serie, and it is clear that you need to have a lot of knowledge to be a good market farmer. Also knowledge is one thing, but to be able to apply it properly is something else, and you need to have the personality to be good at business, that implies being somewhat extroverted and at ease in a social context, even have some personal charisma like you have.  Not everybody has that. So it takes a lot of different qualities in the same person. That being said, I like what you do. Society needs people like you pushing better ways to do things, even though the overall picture is very  complex.

snippet.textDisplay: You are absolutely right, the food issue ties in with so many other issues, such as people no longer having any knowledge of where there food comes from, not knowing what to do with vegetables, families not eating together anymore... However, if each of us start growing our own food, according to our possibilities, we could reach a stage where a family grows enough food so the wife/mother can at least reduce her working hours at her job and spend more time taking care of her own children, which also reduces the amount of money spent on childcare, time spent commuting, stress etc and of course the husband gets a healthy meal when he gets home after work. Depending on  their ages, the children can assist in the garden and learn useful skills. If people then also manage to homeschool their kids we may have a chance to have a society with fewer brainconditioned humans who believe all the ludicrous lies (called "theories" for legal reasons) taught in the official curriculum and in the press. Btw I don't have kids or so but I turned off my TV three years ago and it's amazing how much more time you have. I didn't even have any plants in my apartment and now I grow lots of different vegetables, edible flowers... If I can do it, anyone can!

snippet.textDisplay:
🎯 Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

Small-scale farming envisions replacing mass industrial production with local, human-focused production.
The growth of small farms has been positive over the years, creating local economies and vibrant communities.
The future of farming is food grown with care by people who care, emphasizing human scale and intention.
Local food processing plants and micro plants are expected to emerge, similar to the microbrewery movement.
Grassroots movements in small-scale farming need to resist co-optation by big agriculture and reclaim local markets.
Challenges include land access, valuing food more, and shifting societal views on the importance of quality food.
Education, societal change, and governmental shifts are essential for the success of small farms and a better food system.

snippet.textDisplay:
Inflation has gradually taken place in this well-worn narrative. The song is performed in a melancholic key by YouTubers in search of clicks. In next week's episode, the hypocrisy is replaced by over-enthusiasm in a new project.

snippet.textDisplay: Can someone explain to me the issue with robotics? Or is the problem more with how they are used today, aka for big/industrial ag? I’m on board with like 99% of the bio-intensive small farming material, but what is the difference if someone is manually pushing a BCS to harrow a bed versus a “robotic” machine with say a computer and camera to steer the machine automatically with one button press. What if there were an automated version of the paper pot transplanter, or greens harvester? Why must a human hand hold the drill of a greens harvester for it to be legitimate? I think a future where we use robots/computer vision/ML technology is pretty good, as long as it is tailored for a bio intensive approach which puts ecology and soil health first. Genuinely curious why this would be a bad outcome

snippet.textDisplay:
Bonjour JM,

Would you be interested in discussing Ontario markets? Expanding your concepts into Toronto markets and border cities in Southern Ontario. Startup project in discussion for spring 2024 launch. I'm a firm believer in your proven concepts and feel these farms need to be outside all major cities and in each rural township.

I will be incorporating an aquaponics aspect into business plans and feedstock manufacturing for free range / broiler meat and layer hens.

I'll email and reach out with your contact info listed on your links and remove this comment when I've had some feedback.

Thanks again for the content. We all appreciate it more than you know.
snippet.textOriginal:
Bonjour JM, 

Would you be interested in discussing Ontario markets? Expanding your concepts into Toronto markets and border cities in Southern Ontario. Startup project in discussion for spring 2024 launch. I'm a firm believer in your proven concepts and feel these farms need to be outside all major cities and in each rural township. 

I will be incorporating an aquaponics aspect into business plans and feedstock manufacturing for free range / broiler meat and layer hens.

Thanks again for the content. We all appreciate it more than you know.

snippet.textDisplay:
How is using 10 calories of fossil energy (approximately) per edible calorie of food for grains "efficient"?

Show me anything where small farms would increase carbon footprint.

You are correct it would use more human time, and less ancient hydrocarbons and giant equipment.

Also industrial ag doesn't feed the world, that's a myth, small farms still fees most of the world. Industrial ag gives us more corn and soy to feed to inhumanely and unsanitarily kept animals. And products that are barely food and cause most of the common health problems in the US today, obesity, diabetes, hypertension etc.

And industrial ag isn't even competitive, it's subsidized up the wazoo. They can't stay afloat and rely on government handouts.

Oh and they are causing erosion at unprecedented rates. Read "Dirt, the history of civilizations" for some information on why that is important. Not to mention dead zones in the ocean.

snippet.textDisplay:
@@JB-yg3ew The 10 calories you are quoting includes production and DISTRIBUTION, with distribution being the lions share of those 10 calories of energy.
A case or pallet of (insert veg or fruit name)
needs to get to a supermarket or farmers market.
That pallet being distributed by Big AG has far less carbon emission during transportation, that a pallet brought to a farmers market by a local farmer.
Energy used for DISTRIBUTION from small farms is an ORDER OF MAGNITUDE HIGHER than industrial farms.

Grains also produce the beer and booze humans love so much.

GIant equipment is far more efficient, along with giant farms, then smaller farms.
As they are able to implement modern AG tech to reduce fertilizer and water needs.
Small farms cannot afford this technology.
Smaller farms have a much higher % of roads and paths per acre, than giant farms do. Thus requiring more sq acres of farm land to produce the same tonnage.

Lots of what you say is true, not debating that. But the "solution" of small back to yesteryear farms, is NOT the solution either,
and would actually INCREASE carbon footprint and land usage, along with a whole host of other problems.

PS> most small farm use the same petro based fertilizers and sprays large industrial farms do.
Same for ORGANIC FARMS, they spray just like the big farms, using the same big equipment, difference is their base chemicals have been certified organic.
Other than that, the organic you see in any supermarket or box store is produced the same exact way as industrial AG does.

snippet.textDisplay:
@@JB-yg3ew Organic corn, weed control is done using PROPANE, they have special burners on a tractor, they go down the row, and burn the weeds using PROPANE.
Regular corn, they spray a weed killer.
Both using PETRO,
and the organic is using far more and is more destructive to the environment.

Not as simple as you think.

Also, a combine harvesting corn,
does an acre in about 6 minutes.
It takes about 60 man hours of labor
to accomplish the same without a machine.
Costs about $30-35 to have someone harvest an acre of corn, if you don't have your own equipment.
$35 vs 60 hours of labor
Farmer get about $4.50 a bushel,
and harvest about 180-200 bushels an acre.
Costs about $350-500 an acre to plant corn
for seed and fertilizer, with seed being the majority cost.
You do the math.

snippet.textDisplay: ​@jeshurunfarm ignore the terms and labels. Make the human connections with your customers. Ignore the corporate food system, focus on your small farm and how many people you could actually connect with. Be at your scale. Take the tiny fraction of the larger market you can access. Scaling up small scale farming is not so much about existing small farms getting bigger but is more about incressing the number of small farms in the system, each connecting with small points in the market.

snippet.textDisplay: @@spacemanspiffy6596 All attachments ride on the ground to be honest.  You're not going to be able to mow while holding the Flail Mower off the ground, it just isn't feasible.  The flail JM is using in this video is the RollerBlade model.  The rear roller on the mower is what determines the height of the cut.  The height adjustment crank on the top of the mower adjusts the angle of the dome in relation to the roller.

snippet.textDisplay: This would probably only work for transplants, not direct seeding. In compost, seeds would dry out rapidly in compost because there is so much air between aggregates compared to soil. And mowing wouldn’t necessarily kill the vetch. That requires the power harrow or tiller implements. Without killing the crop first. it would require a very thick layer of compost, I’d say 3-4” or more, so that the mowed crop would not easily penetrate through. Basically you’d be using the compost AS your tarp, providing occultation over the soil. The last thing you’d want is a cover crop growing as weeds in your cash crop, after it has been supercharged with inches of compost.
snippet.textOriginal: This would probably only work for transplants, not direct seeding. snippet.textDisplay: @@goodboysongs to add further, Vetch is very hard to terminate via mowing unless it's in the reproductive stage of growth, otherwise, it comes back readily. That is why I don't use vetch anymore in my cover crop mixes. I use peas, beans, and biennial and annual clovers instead (almost as good (or in the case of some of the biennial sweet covers, just as good), but way easier to manage). I still have volunteer vetch in my fields from the last time I used it and didn't get it killed 100%, and that was 4 years ago.  Shallow tillage (1" into the soil) is a better way to terminate vetch if you don't have time to wait until it's flowering (to mow), or time to tarp it.
snippet.textOriginal: @@goodboysongs to add further, Vetch is very hard to terminate via mowing unless it's in the reproductive stage of growth, otherwise, it comes back readily. snippet.textDisplay: My idea is to have public farms like we have public schools. And ideally incorporate the two. Capitalism has destroyed place and community. Psychologically and spiritually we have created an unsustainable civilization, let alone agri"culture". We are engaged in agribusiness, hence the burnout and unsatisfaction. Public farms can be democratically managed but more importantly farmers (principals) and labor (teachers) and the vegetables (students?! Hah!) engage not as market competetors with one another but as vitally linked, mutually supported (yes, this happens already to a certain local extent and it is the most satisfying part of farming to me) meta organism. The Amish do not burn out as they are united in faith and purpose. The English burnout because we try to do everything ourselves and have no safety net, financially or emotionally. The English need to harness the philosophy of deep democracy and faith in nature that combine to create good will and good decision making. Consumers connect at community farms and private ones as well but the number of accessable farms is small. Begin by having every school hire a farmer with the 5 year plan to be producing enough produce and even livestock, if possible, for every family in the service area of the school and pay for it with property taxes, just like the school. Federal and state budgets have so much waste that if you took 10 % of that waste you can actually pay living wages to every teacher AND provide secure liveihoods to the growers who are providing a vital NATIONAL SECURITY ASSET: FOOD! The "Free" market has only given crap food for the poor and nutritious food for the well to do. Climate destruction is already destroying farms and farmers. It is already too late to gaurantee food security going forward so localize now, intensely, and in all aspects of production. Consumers are everywhere so producers should be too.

snippet.textDisplay: It’s sad and shocking to see the reactions of some people towards other people who, even after diligence and patience and careful daily planning and care for years, eventually realize and decide that it’s time move on from farming and leaving the countryside to a different state or country, some even do go back to the city and are happier there. Factually, there is no shame for doing so, and there shouldn’t be! I’m so sick of these false Christian, religious, and atheist rural hypocrites who look for any excuse as to why someone simply decides farming doesn’t work for them. That’s okay if it doesn’t work for you! I personally hate anything rural and to do with farming or gardening, animal husbandry, etc. They don’t make me a better person and God doesn’t say I have to do them to lead a Godly life and help others. It all boils down to - your family do what ethically works best for your family. We don’t all like the same things or live in the same places, etc. A country person and a city person who are Godly, ethical, civil, courteous, even if they are both self sufficient and hard working, who try to live in peace with those around them are always welcome at my table, as they say. If people want to demean and falsely accuse or censor city or country people, we’ll that speaks volumes of how wrong that person is and they have serious problems that they need to work out with God. Bottom line - if you decide farming or gardening doesn’t work for you, then I say to those people that’s great and I still support them and they’re welcome to visit at our home in the city!

snippet.textDisplay: Burn out is common these days primarily due to unreasonable pressures that one puts on themselves. First several JM's sentences summed up most reasons . It is one thing to hear good advice but another to understand it and apply it. Listen to JM! He has plenty of experience. ....  The average age group that is entering into homesteading  and market gardening is predisposed to certain ideas and  performance expectations. Nature has it's own rhythm and a farmer must adapt to it as well as unpredictability of a very complicated system that thrives on diversity. Idealistic visions of farming are certain to fail and if one is not psychologically strong and prepared for failure then farm  failure is inevitable. Again, JM has said this in this video but it is important to really hear and understand what he is saying. .... Putting up with the rat race but knowing that the cheque is in the mail makes days bearable.  Working all Winter and Spring while consuming resources while not knowing the certain outcome takes balls, tenacity, endurance, bravery and so many other qualities that one can do without while working in the corporate world.  🤮. You can't call your growing bed an asshole and unleash a personal attack campaign that turns into a popularity contest. Screaming at a wall does not produce favourable growing conditions, but it can indicate the state of ones mental health. Jm's closing remarks are of this theme.  Are you are still reading this? Great!  ..... Take a greenhouse for example. The skills that are needed to manage a greenhouse are more of engineering nature than botanical or biological. Yes you need all of those skills or pay for them. Just one bad spore colony can wipe out your crop.  .... How many people are skilled enough to undertake farming? The ones still farming, is the answer. Farming is not a lifestyle one can take on as a fashion. It can be lonely and discouraging, but when all goes well and you learned something that you can apply and the bumper crop is in and all customers are thankful and when all bills are paid AHHHHHH, that is the moment when I look back and say: LIFE IS GREAT AND I WOULD NOT BE HAPPY DOING ANYTHING ELSE! .  . I often wonder, how many unhappy wives and children are suffering because dad wanted to be a self dependent survivalist. All need to be on board for a farm to succeed. Make friends that understand.  ........ Happy growing!
